fields.detail: Consider how the public perceives or could perceive this project in light of existing water rights, current and future or planned public access, and potential landscape-altering engineering (cutting of riparian forest, flooding, river capture, etc.). Will or do members of the public actively challenge the project? Does public perception pose an additional challenge to restoration?

fields.title: Contamination or Hazardous Waste

fields.detail:
Consider whether flow conditions in the river are likely to connect the river to the floodplain. Is the river too entrenched? Do water releases from upstream dams or consumptive water withdrawals from upstream limit flow within the reach such that the floodplain is disconnected? Are there other flow barriers?

This question should be answered at the reach scale. The reach scale should generally include the length of river consisting of the same or similar gradient and channel confinement. Confluences with large tributaries or changes in sediment materials may also be used to delineate reaches (Skidmore et al. 2011). 

A relevant “reach scale” may already be determined for your project area, based on river assessments or known conditions in the area. Consult available watershed assessments or other relevant documents to determine whether a reach has already been determined for your property or project site.
fields.name: infrastructure_constraints
fields.question: Are there water withdrawals, levees or upstream dams that affect the flow conditions or geomorphology of the floodplain in this reach?
fields.title: Infrastructure constraints

fields.name: substrate
fields.question: Substrate? --Question to be removed--
fields.title: Substrate

fields.detail:
If gravel or larger material is available within the river, is it also being deposited locally, rather than being transported downstream? Upstream dams, ongoing instream or floodplain aggregate extract, and capture of sediment by existing floodplain pits may all limit sediment availability in the river. Channel and watershed characteristics may naturally limit availability of sediment, and bank armoring, straightening, and dredging may limit sediment deposition.

Suggested methods for answering this include:
 Review of a sediment budget for the watershed if one has been produced. 
 Examination of sequences of aerial photographs, looking for evidence of aggradation and erosion of in-channel features such as gravel bars or islands
 Mapping of the existence and impacts of sediment-capturing features or processes such as upstream dams, ongoing aggregate mining, other pits
 Simple visual inspection.

This question should be answered at the reach scale. The reach scale should generally include the length of river consisting of the same or similar gradient and channel confinement. Confluences with large tributaries or changes in sediment materials may also be used to delineate reaches (Skidmore et al. 2011). 

A relevant “reach scale” may already be determined for your project area, based on river assessments or known conditions in the area. Consult available watershed assessments or other relevant documents to determine whether a reach has already been determined for your property or project site.
fields.name: material_availability
fields.question: Is gravel or larger sized material available in the river system, and is it being deposited within the channel or floodplain?
fields.title: Material availability

fields.detail:
This question should be answered at the reach scale. The reach scale should generally include the length of river consisting of the same or similar gradient and channel confinement. Confluences with large tributaries or changes in sediment materials may also be used to delineate reaches (Skidmore et al. 2011). 

A relevant “reach scale” may already be determined for your project area, based on river assessments or known conditions in the area. Consult available watershed assessments or other relevant documents to determine whether a reach has already been determined for your property or project site.

Floodplain characteristics such as channel gradient and valley type are important determinants of floodplain restoration responsiveness and can be used to assess the benefits of restoration within a given reach. Gradient controls the movement of water, materials, and species throughout the river system. Valley type determines river-floodplain interaction, habitat, and species occurrence.

Consider characteristics such as occurrence at the confluence of two rivers, areas of coldwater upwelling, habitat complexity that supports greater biodiversity, etc...
fields.name: location_in_floodplain
fields.question: Is the property located in an ecologically/hydrologically rich/important spot in the watershed?
fields.title: Location in watershed
